sentences.sentence_tlingit: Yú haa aaní áyú yú haa aaní, Ḵákʼw áyú yóo duwasáakw; Dleit Ḵáa x̱ʼéinax̱ ḵu.aa, Basket Bay.
sentences.sentence_english: That land of ours, that land of ours is called Ḵakʼw; but in English Basket Bay.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Chʼu tle éeḵdáx̱ yaa wunadéini teen áwé, kei atʼaa.íxʼch, “Dei éeḵdáx̱ yaawadáaaaaa.” Chʼu tle yóo hít kát aa, aa x̱ʼéit was g̱adutéenín, “Éeḵdáx̱ yaawadáaaaaa.” Yéi áyú has du x̱oox̱ yaa g̱axíxch.
sentences.sentence_english: As soon as the tide started corning up he would cry out, “The tiiiiiide is starting uuuuuuup.” As if it were put in his mouth the one sitting on top of the house repeated “The tiiiiiide is starting uuuuuuuup.” This was how they passed the word.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Shóogoonáx̱, aadéi yóo at kawdiyayi yé, yá Lingít, shayadiheni aa yéi sh kalneek yá ixkéenax̱ áyá haat haa wsidáḵ, yá ixkée.
sentences.sentence_english: For the things that happened to the Tlingits in the beginning, many say we migrated here through the south, the south.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Á áyá shayadiheni aa, Shtaxʼhéen yíknáx̱ yaa wsidaaḵ, Shtaxʼhéen yíknáx̱. Yá ax̱ éesh hás has dutlakw nooch, yá Shtaxʼhéen yíknáx̱, yaa has wusdaag̱í.
sentences.sentence_english: And, you know, there are many who migrated down the Stikine River, down the Stikine River. The story of my fathers is always told, of when they migrated down the Stikine.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Á áyá Jilḵáatnáx̱ yeiḵ uwa.át yá ax̱ éesh hás x̱oonxʼi, yá Daḵlʼaweidí.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Yá uháan, yá Deisheetaanx̱ haa sateeyí, chʼa yaadachóon áyá, yéi has akanéek, yá ixkéenáx̱ áyá, yá ixkéenáx̱. Gootʼaanáx̱ sá kwshé yeiḵ wutuwa.át uháan.
sentences.sentence_english: Those of us who are Deisheetaan, still tell it like this, as coming from the South, from the south. I wonder where we came out, those of us.

sentences.sentence_english: From there we finally went northward, northward, we began searching.

lines.line_english: From there we finally went northward,

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Shayadiheni yé kawduwa.aaḵw.
sentences.sentence_english: They tried many places.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Shayadiheni yé aanx̱ wududliyéx̱. Wé gaaw áwé, yá Xutsnoowú yax̱ʼáak, yax̱ iltʼéexʼ, tʼéexʼ kát aa uwa.át, wé gaaw áwé, aag̱áa daak ḵuwligasʼi yé.
sentences.sentence_english: Villages were founded in many places. At that time across from Brown Bear Fort, when it froze, they walked over ice at that time, at the point when they moved across.

lines.line_english: Villages were founded in many places.
at the point when they moved across.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Ha! shayadiheni aa yá haa x̱oonxʼí, yá Deisheetaan, yá dáaḵ káxʼ yéi aa dax̱yatee.
sentences.sentence_english: Well! There are many who are our relatives, these Deisheetaan, some are living in the Interior.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Chʼu chʼáagudáx̱, áa yéi has yatee.
sentences.sentence_english: Since long ago, they have been living there.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Shayadihéin, yá Nahóowu, áa yéi yatee, ḵa yá ax̱ saayí, Shaadaaxʼ tsú áa yéi yatee, yá dáaḵ ká.
sentences.sentence_english: They are many, Nahóowu lives there and this namesake of mine. Shaadaaxʼ is also there, in the Interior.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Á áyá a daa yoo tux̱atángi áyá, hás, chʼu chʼáagudáx̱ áa yéi s teeyí, has du een gé yá woochdáx̱ haa wusdaag̱éen.
sentences.sentence_english: You know, thinking about them, if they’ve been living there a long time, maybe we separated and migrated from them.

chʼu chʼáagudáx̱ áa yéi s teeyí,

sentences.sentence_english: This is what I’m thinking about them.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Ách yá éilʼ kát haa kawdiyáa, uháan ḵu.aa.
sentences.sentence_english: This is why we gathered here on the coast.

sentences.sentence_tlingit: Chʼa yéi áyá x̱ʼakḵwanáaḵ, yá sh kalneek.
